AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Magistrate Judge: judge who signed the Report and Recommendation, outlining the process for filing objections to the findings, conclusions, and recommendations
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol: law enforcement agency involved in the arrest and investigation of human smuggling cases, with agents conducting patrols and stops on highways such as U.S. Highway 59 and Farm-to-Market Road 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Police Department: Involved in the traffic stop of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and cooperated with United States Border Patrol.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: court that interpreted Agent Trevino's testimony about vehicles going off the road on Farm-to-Market Road 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. Highway 59: highway with a checkpoint that can be avoided by taking Farm-to-Market Road 2050, mentioned as part of the route taken by smugglers
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Immigration Checkpoint: Checkpoint where the initial stop occurred and interviews were conducted
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Immigration Checkpoint Building: Location where IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. was held in a cell before being interviewed
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Border Patrol Station Parking Lot: parking lot adjacent to the Freer immigration checkpoint; nearby area where vehicles turned southbound onto Farm-to-Market Road 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol Agent Jorge: agent who conducted the cross-examination and provided testimony about the suspicious behavior of the vehicles involved in the smuggling operation
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol Agent Ignaci: defendant associated with the black Dodge pickup truck; provided inconsistent information about vehicle ownership
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Farm-to-Market Road 2050: farm-to-market road used by smugglers to avoid checkpoints on U.S. Highway 59 and Highway 16, exhibiting suspicious behavior such as going on and off the road multiple times
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hebbronville Checkpoint: border patrol checkpoint mentioned by Defendant as his point of origin
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Highway 16: highway that can be used by smugglers to reach major highways going north, considered a safer route once reached due to the absence of additional checkpoints
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. Highway 359: highway mentioned as a location where the black Dodge pickup truck was headed
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Immigration Checkpoint and Hebbron: checkpoints avoided by smugglers using routes via Farm-to-Market Road 2050, U.S. Highway 59, and U.S. Highway 359
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hertz Dallas-Fort Worth: Location where a rental vehicle was registered, contributing to Agent Trevino's suspicion due to its out-of-town registration.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mills Bennett Road: dirt road intersecting Farm-to-Market Road 2050, approximately five to six miles south of the Freer immigration checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.San Pablo Road: road that can be used to access Highway 16, providing an alternative route for smugglers to avoid checkpoints
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Moglia Ranch House: ranch house located near San Pablo Road, ownership unknown to Agent Trevino
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Stag Ranch Trailer: trailer located near San Pablo Road, ownership unknown to Agent Trevino
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Santo Nino Road: also known as Dinn Ranch, extends east from Farm-to-Market Road 2050; provides access to Highway 16
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Dinn Ranch: also known as Santo Nino Road, extends east from Farm-to-Market Road 2050; provides access to Highway 16
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Officer Reyes: conducted a traffic stop of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR., noticed he was nervous and shaking during the interaction; issued a citation and impounded the black Dodge pickup truck due to unclear ownership and lack of insurance information
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate 35: most direct highway to Dallas, Texas or San Antonio from the area where Agent Trevino encountered the suspicious vehicles
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Laredo, Texas: location at the southern terminus of the route taken by smugglers, mentioned as a starting point for the journey to Dallas, Texas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Dallas, Texas: destination city for smuggled individuals, located at the northern end of the route taken by smugglers
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.San Antonio: city mentioned as a potential destination for smuggled individuals
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol Agent Hugo B: agent who arrested IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. based on probable cause that he was participating in a smuggling operation with RICARDO RODRIGUEZ, JR.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Officer Reymundo Reyes: conducted a traffic stop of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR., noticed he was nervous and shaking during the interaction; issued a citation and impounded the black Dodge pickup truck due to unclear ownership and lack of insurance information
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Department of Homeland Sec: Received a phone call regarding an attempted alien smuggling event and conducted interviews at the Freer immigration checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Government: Prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures, with protections extending to brief investigatory stops of persons or vehicles that fall short of traditional arrest.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: a court that has noted the order of vehicles in a smuggling venture is not significant, and has addressed arrangements such as "load vehicle-scout vehicle" used by smugglers
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. Highway 277: highway with a checkpoint that can be avoided by taking Ranch Road 2523 north to Highway 377
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Highway 377: highway that can be used to avoid the checkpoint on Highway 277 by taking Ranch Road 2523 north to Highway 377
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ranch Road 2523: road that can be used to avoid the checkpoint on Highway 277 by taking it north to Highway 377
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Highway 85: a common smuggling route that avoids immigration checkpoints
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country with lawful bounds for stops, governing principles for traffic stops and arrests
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Supreme Court of the United States: high court that has long held certain principles regarding reasonableness in traffic stops and arrests, including that the constitutional reasonableness of traffic stops does not depend on the actual motivations of individual officers involved. Refused to authorize investigative interrogations at law enforcement stations on less than probable cause or consent.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court: governing body for traffic stops and arrests, applying principles set out in Terry
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Judge: judge responsible for conducting independent reviews of motions to suppress evidence and ensuring adherence to lawful standards for traffic stops and arrests
defendant associated with the white Malibu sedan, arrested for transporting illegal aliens and providing statements during the hearing about the convenience of the route from Laredo, Texas to Dallas, Texas for smugglers
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ford Motor Company: manufacturer of vehicles commonly used by oil companies, such as Ford F-150s and Ford F-250s
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Corinth, Texas: location where the black Dodge pickup truck was registered, near Dallas, Texas; a suburb approximately twenty to twenty-five miles north of Dallas, Texas
defendant associated with the black Dodge pickup truck, arrested for suspected involvement in human smuggling
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.J. Scott Hacker: does not consider the fact that the black Dodge pickup truck was riding low to contribute to the reasonable suspicion for the stop
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas Department of Transportation: prepared district traffic maps of Farm-to-Market Road 2050 and U.S. Highway 59, indicating traffic flow data primarily collected and determined by the Transportation, Planning, and Programming Division in Austin; has a Laredo Division with a Director of Transportation, Planning and Development
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas Department of Transportation, Tran: collects and determines traffic flow data for district traffic maps
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas Department of Transportation, Lare: has a Director of Transportation, Planning and Development who testified about the accuracy of traffic flow data
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hertz Rental Car Company: rental car company whose vehicles are used by smugglers to avoid losing personal vehicles in case of getting caught
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Bruni, Texas: location at the southern terminus of Farm-to-Market Road 2050 that could have been reached via U.S. Highway 359 for a more direct route
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ranchitos Las Lomas: starting point of the journey on U.S. Highway 59 where a more direct route to Bruni would be Farm-to-Market Road 2895 instead of Farm-to-Market Road 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Farm-to-Market Road 2895: alternative farm-to-market road that would have been a more direct route to Bruni from Ranchitos Las Lomas on U.S. Highway 59
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.white Malibu sedan: vehicle involved in the smuggling operation, driven by RICARDO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and exhibiting suspicious behavior such as driving in tandem with another vehicle
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.black Dodge pickup truck: vehicle involved in the smuggling operation, driven by IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.white Malibu sedan and black Dodge picku: Vehicles involved in the smuggling operation; used to transport undocumented individuals and exhibited suspicious behavior such as going on and off Farm-to-Market Road 2050 multiple times
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Houston: city mentioned as a potential destination for smuggled individuals
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Department of Homeland Sec: Conducted interviews with RICARDO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Highway 59 and U.S. Highwa: highways with checkpoints that can be avoided by taking Farm-to-Market Road 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Constitution: governing document that outlines the framework for lawful arrests and searches
